summary: This document is an email chain from July 2020 among U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) personnel discussing the processing of Touhy requests from victims of Jeffrey Epstein involved in civil litigation. It details internal coordination on responding to requests for documents, approvals, and interactions with victim's counsel, including Roberta Kaplan, and references the Maxwell team's sign-off on responses.

persons.name: Roberta Kaplan
persons.context: Attorney representing an Epstein victim in civil litigation, to whom the USANYS plans to send a Touhy response letter.

persons.name: Geoff
persons.context: Referred to as the 'responsible' U.S. Attorney who may need to handle a Touhy-referred subpoena from another district.

connections.description: Kaplan is legal counsel for victims making Touhy requests for documents related to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Internal Coordination on Touhy Request
events.description: USANYS personnel discuss finalizing and sending a response letter to an Epstein victim's Touhy request, noting the Maxwell team has signed off.

events.title: Approval of Document Production to Victim
events.description: An AUSA notes that a Jane Doe victim's identity is known and approves sending previously disclosed grand jury subpoena materials to her.

events.title: Follow-up on Epstein Victim Touhy Request
events.description: Prosecutors discuss a call with victim's counsel to explain no further documents will be produced, and address requests for materials from the S.D. Fla. investigation.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York was processing Touhy requests from Epstein victims involved in civil litigation in 2020.
The 'Maxwell team' (presumably Ghislaine Maxwell's legal team) reviewed and signed off on the government's response letters to victim requests.

The office possessed FBI investigative files from the S.D. Fla. Epstein investigation but deliberately avoided obtaining files from the S.D. Fla. U.S. Attorney's Office due to conflict and discovery issues.
Prosecutors referenced a prior non-prosecution agreement from S.D. Fla. as a reason for not stepping into that district's shoes.
Internal discussions show coordination between criminal and civil divisions on handling victim requests while protecting ongoing investigations and grand jury materials.
